fMRI study investigating social cognition (positivity motivation) comparing close vs. non-close others; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults (though exact ages not reported). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in adults; include for full-text review to confirm sample age range and health status.

fMRI study of social processing (eye contact and spontaneous mimicry) in human participants. It reports neural mechanisms in mPFC/STS/mirror system and is empirical (not a review). Participants are described as human (n=20) consistent with healthy adults; if age details are missing, include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants (n=15) viewed and rated short movie-clips of social interactions—directly addresses social processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study where human participants (n=25) performed prosocial decisions toward family—a social cognition task involving mentalizing and self-control. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This study used EEG, not functional MRI, and investigated diagnostic EEG measures in Alzheimer’s disease versus controls rather than social-related processing tasks in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the fMRI and task-related inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in normal adult volunteers using videos of positive and negative social encounters—directly assesses social processing in healthy adults (age range consistent with 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Original fMRI study in healthy adults examining social interaction vs solitary context during episodic memory tasks (social processing). Meets inclusion (social-related fMRI in healthy adults); not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info.

fMRI study examining dmPFC activity during impression formation—a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but lacks explicit age/health details; include for full-text review to confirm.

3T BOLD fMRI study in 29 healthy subjects (14F/15M) during processing of humorous cartoons — a social-cognition/emotion task (perception and appraisal of others’ emotions). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm age range and additional details.

Abstract reports an fMRI neuroimaging study examining brain responses to observed social interactions (mirror and mentalizing networks) using point-light displays. This fits the review objective of social processing in humans. The abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Study used resting-state fMRI connectivity analyses rather than a task-based fMRI scan involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires participants perform a social-related task during fMRI, so exclude based on abstract information.

Four fMRI experiments (n=98) in healthy adults examining social cognition (self, friends, unknown others), testing closeness/similarity—clearly a social-related task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study examining social gaze effects on action control (social-related processing) in human participants. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects but does not report ages/health explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI was used with healthy adult participants (n=64) performing a social cognition task (inferring others’ preferences vs. own), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract.

fMRI conducted while healthy participants played charades (a social communication task) measuring neural responses during interaction; fits social processing in adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (familiarity judgments of personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces). Addresses perception/understanding of others and social cognition; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

This is a review article (Annual Review) summarizing fMRI and lesion studies rather than reporting original fMRI data on human participants; exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) is met.

fMRI study using a socio-emotional preference task (social preference judgments of human faces), directly addressing social processing. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides clear task and imaging methods meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining empathy/affiliation by having (presumably healthy) participants imagine self, loved-one, and stranger in painful situations—addresses social-related processing (attachment, perception of others) in humans and is not a review.

fMRI study where participants engaged in live face-to-face social interaction and joint attention tasks; reports neural activation in social cognition regions. No indication it is a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages explicitly, but participants appear to be healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm age/health criteria.

fMRI study of charitable donation decisions—a social decision-making task involving social cognition and value computation. Involves healthy adult subjects (not explicitly ages but typical sample). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study using a naturalistic joint-attention/social cognition task (representing what another person sees), examining perception/understanding of others in humans. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study reports an fMRI experiment where healthy participants made social-related judgments (self vs friend personality and memory), matching the review objective. Abstract does not indicate clinical populations; if sample details (age/health) are unclear, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating empathy and social cognition (perception/understanding of others) in humans; no indication of clinical populations. Abstract lacks explicit age range but clearly examines social-related processing in healthy participants, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant details.

Original fMRI study using the Movie for the Assessment of Social Cognition examining Theory of Mind/mental state reasoning (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports task-based fMRI in naturalistic social processing. Participant health and ages not specified—include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65) and sample details.

Abstract describes a behavioral neuropsychological study of patients with frontal and temporo-parietal lesions; no functional MRI was conducted and participants are clinical patients rather than healthy adults performing fMRI social tasks, so it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in 26 healthy adult participants investigating how social context and perceived agency modulate neural responses to others' pain—addresses perception/understanding of others and social interaction. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining audiovisual integration of facial movements and non-verbal vocalizations—clearly a social-communication/perception task. Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant age or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI was used to measure neural responses to masked facial emotions (social-affiliative/attachment processing) in a sample of 51 healthy adults. The task probes perception of others’ emotional signals (social processing). Not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study using the Trust Game examines reciprocity (social cognition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages or clinical status; no exclusion criteria clearly met. Include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).

The study uses fMRI to investigate mental state decoding (Perception and Understanding of Others) in healthy adult participants (native Japanese and white American). It reports neural correlates of social cognition and is an empirical fMRI study (not a review), meeting the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of empathy for pain (affect sharing and self–other distinction) using video stimuli in human participants, addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Involves healthy participants (no clinical population indicated) and is an original empirical study, not a review.

fMRI study examining social processing (pupillary exchange/social salience) in human subjects, directly relevant to social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they are healthy adults; therefore include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating social-related auditory perception (social interaction signals) in humans, meeting the review objective. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI study where human participants observed social vs individual actions; investigates social cognition (gaze effects) and reports brain activity (dMPFC). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text confirmation of participant demographics and health status.

Event-related fMRI study explicitly examines responses to social (face) versus non-social targets, directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly say ‘healthy’, so include for full-text review to confirm that at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65) was studied.

fMRI study of social processing (gaze shifts, joint attention) in humans; meets the review objective. Abstract implies behavioural and neural responses in participants (likely healthy adults) but does not state ages/health explicitly—include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (judgments about social groups/individuals) in human participants, not a review. It aligns with the review objective and likely used healthy adult participants; age not specified but inclusion warranted for full-text review to confirm exact ages and sample details.

fMRI study investigating social perception (approach with happy/angry expressions) in human participants. Addresses social processing relevant to the review. Participant health status and ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65.

fMRI study examining perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication/perception of others) in human participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social exchange processing (Wason selection task). Addresses social-related processing and is empirical (not a review). Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants involving social cognition (attribution of intentions to human vs computer‑generated music); reports neural activations in mental-state attribution network. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in healthy human participants performing social-related tasks (gaze and pointing) probing social communication/Perception of Others. Study reports BOLD responses and neural loci; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was performed in 18 healthy adult participants during a social motor response learning task that involves inferring others' intentions/goals, meeting the review’s social-processing and healthy adult criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Original study used fMRI during an emotion-attribution task (SELF/OTHER) probing empathy and social cognition in human subjects. This addresses social-related processing in (presumably adult) healthy participants and is an original research article, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social fMRI studies; include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining self-recognition (face and name), which fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ social processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

Primary research using fMRI during a social interactive task (and non-social control) in human subjects; examines social cognition and in-group/out-group interactions relevant to perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in humans investigating neural processing of social hierarchy (social status), clearly a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy participants (no indication of patient groups) and is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study with healthy volunteers performing a social cognition (theory-of-mind) task examining cooperation and deception, which fits the review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study examining observation, imitation, and production of facial expressions and social hand gestures—clearly addresses social communication processing in humans. Abstract does not state participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of participants observing social interaction (adult instructing child; child’s correct/incorrect actions) probing processing of others’ behavior—matches social cognition constructs. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and uses task-based fMRI. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was performed during implicit and explicit processing of emotional facial expressions—a social communication task involving perception/understanding of others. The sample includes 12 healthy subjects. Abstract lacks participant ages, so full-text needed to confirm age 17–65; include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social interaction simulation probing friendship (type of relationship, emotional valence) in human participants (N=28). Task targets social processes (affiliation, empathy, reward). Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant group appears to be healthy adults; full text can confirm ages, but abstract provides sufficient information to include for this review.

fMRI study of communicative speech (social communication) in 'normal subjects' reporting activation in social-cognitive regions. Meets the review objective of social-related processing in healthy humans. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and sample details.

fMRI study of self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognition) in healthy adults; tasks explicitly probe perception/understanding of self and others. Abstract indicates experimental fMRI data in human participants and meets inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Functional MRI was used while participants judged the relatedness of social concepts, a social-cognition task. The study examines social concept processing in humans (presumably healthy adult participants) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining social cognition (perception/understanding of others) in human participants; participants appear to be healthy adult volunteers. Meets inclusion of functional MRI during a social-related task in adults and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

fMRI study using an interactive social task (competitive reaction time provoking retaliation) in healthy male subjects, directly probing social interaction/reactive aggression and related affective/cognitive processes. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant group described as healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review.

fMRI study of face perception and emotional expression processing (social cognition). Abstract indicates human observers and social-related task (faces/fear), but does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study examining spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception—a social-cognition task. Participants performed a perceptual one-back task while scanned. Abstract does not report participant ages explicitly but implies healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining recognition of visual feedback as self vs other, addressing perception/understanding of self and others—a social-related construct. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study manipulating eye gaze and socially relevant facial expressions in virtual characters, directly investigating social interaction and social communication. Abstract describes an fMRI task in human participants (likely healthy adults) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers using social-cognition tasks (theory of mind and empathy). Functional imaging during social-related task, healthy participant group included, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study examining processing of angry vs. neutral voice prosody (social communication/perception of others) with attention manipulation; involves healthy adult participants and reports neural responses. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI in 12 healthy adult volunteers performing self vs familiar vs unfamiliar face judgments — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of self/others). Participants are healthy and within 17–65 (college-aged). Study is original research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (impression formation about other people vs objects), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. No exclusion criteria met; abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports two fMRI experiments probing understanding of intentions in social interactions (theory-of-mind), which is a social-related task in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/age not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm that at least one healthy adult group (17–65) was tested.

fMRI study in 19 healthy volunteers examining neural responses during evaluation of guilt and embarrassment—self-conscious, social-cognitive tasks (ToM-related). Meets inclusion: task is social-related processing and participants are healthy adults. Not a review.

fMRI study where healthy individuals performed a social task (cooperation vs competition), addressing social cognition/understanding of others. Participants appear to be human subjects (adult sample implied); study is original research (not a review). Therefore meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social gaze processing (social perception/understanding of others), meeting the review topic. Abstract does not specify participant ages or clinical status; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.

fMRI study in normal (healthy) subjects engaging in a social-related task (watching movie clips of everyday social interactions). This directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but inclusion criteria met; recommend full-text for confirmation.

fMRI was performed while participants made social judgments (gender judgments of faces learned as cooperators/defectors via Prisoner’s Dilemma), addressing social cognition/perception of others in healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI explicitly measured neural responses during trustworthiness judgments of faces—a social perception/understanding of others—meeting the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status; include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (age 17–65).

fMRI study in (healthy) volunteers performing social-related tasks (empathy, judging others’ emotional states and forgivability). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during social cognition in adults; no exclusion criteria apparent. Include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring amygdala responses to racial ingroup/outgroup face stimuli—addresses social perception/understanding of others in human participants who identify as White or Black (healthy adults). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI.
fMRI study using a social interaction recognition task (social perception/understanding) that includes a healthy adult participant group (ages 20–41), satisfying inclusion criteria; not a review.

fMRI study using social-emotional stimuli (angry/happy faces) in an implicit emotion processing task involving perception of others (gender identification), matching the review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participants were healthy adults or ages 17–65, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This fMRI study measured brain responses while healthy human participants (n=25) viewed colored faces and scrambled images — a social-perception task (face perception/understanding of others). It is an empirical fMRI study (not a review) and involves healthy participants. Ages are not reported in the abstract, so I have moderate confidence and recommend inclusion for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI was performed during tasks comparing touching an animate (human) vs inanimate target, addressing social/interpersonal touch and sensorimotor prediction—clearly a social-related task in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study of social processing (direct/reflected self and other evaluations). Includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range. Not a review; meets social-task and participant criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining brain responses to interpersonal manual touch (another person touching subject). Interpersonal touch constitutes social-related processing (affiliation/social interaction). Abstract indicates task and healthy adult participants; no exclusion criteria met.

Abstract examines neuronal networks during the ultimatum game (a social decision-making task) and references brain activations consistent with an fMRI social-processing study. However, it does not specify participant ages or explicitly state fMRI use. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and imaging methods.

Abstract reports fMRI neural responses during a task in which participants judged ambiguous social interactions after tactile stimulation, addressing social perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant group likely healthy adults; full text can confirm demographics.

fMRI study using a face-viewing paradigm (socially relevant: perception/understanding of others). Sample spans childhood through adulthood, so includes adult participants; no disorders are reported, implying healthy subjects. Abstract does not state exact adult ages, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

Functional MRI study using a social-related task (perception of biological motion/ social perception) including healthy adult participants (adults reported) within the target age range; not a review. Abstract gives sufficient information to include for meta-analysis.

Event-related fMRI study investigating gender perception from faces—a social perception/understanding of others task. Neural responses during a social-related task are reported. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state health status, so full-text review is needed to confirm participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI study where participants made judgments about affiliation and isolation (social perception constructs). Involves healthy younger and older adult groups; abstract lacks precise ages but includes social-related processing and BOLD fMRI. Include for full-text to confirm age ranges and participant health.

fMRI study of social communication (communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations) clearly addresses social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.

fMRI study in healthy human participants includes an adult group (25–35). The task probes affective (social-affiliative) touch processing—an aspect of social/affective perception—so it fits the review’s social-related processing domain. Abstract is primary research (not a review). Some uncertainty because touch was passive rather than explicit social interaction.

fMRI study of self-face recognition addressing ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’, a social-related construct. Uses healthy participants (adult sample implied) performing a task during scanning. Not a review. Abstract provides enough relevance; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

fMRI study investigating perception of face identity and eye gaze—both social-communication/perception processes—in human participants. Not a review. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, it clearly involves social-related processing during fMRI, so it meets inclusion or at minimum warrants full-text review.

fMRI study examining gaze-direction effects on face processing—clearly a social perception task. Abstract does not specify participant demographics or ages, so inclusion of healthy adults cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adult participants (17–65).

Abstract describes fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social task (a deception game between pairs), meeting the review’s requirement of functional MRI during social processing. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults age 17–65).

fMRI study using attributional decision tasks probing self-responsibility and self-serving bias (social cognition: perception/understanding of self). Abstract refers to 'normal subjects' indicating healthy participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Information is sufficient to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception/Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Uses healthy human participants (‘normal’ subjects). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient task and population information to warrant inclusion for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants performing explicit and implicit emotion-recognition tasks (social communication/perception of others). Addresses social-related processing in healthy adults and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review—meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating perception/understanding of self vs others (body-part images), which fits social-related processing (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). Abstract implies human fMRI participants but does not report ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

Human fMRI study measuring neural responses to observed hand/foot actions after sensorimotor training—addresses perception/understanding of others (social processing). Participants appear to be healthy adults; task is social-related. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study examining neural representations of self (general and contextual self judgments), which fits 'Perception and Understanding of Self' social-processing. Abstract implies healthy adult participants across cultures; ages not specified. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and health.

fMRI study in healthy young adult males performing an explicit emotion recognition task (social perception of others’ emotions). Participants are healthy and within adult age range; task is social-related. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of audiovisual non-verbal emotional perception (faces and voices) addressing social communication and perception of others in humans; not a review and abstract implies healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used during social-related tasks (direct and reflected self-appraisals — perception/understanding of self). The study includes a healthy adult group aged 23–30 (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract examines neural correlates of prosody perception/production and links to empathy—clearly a social-communication neural study in likely healthy adults. However the abstract does not explicitly state an fMRI scan was used nor participant ages. Insufficient detail to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant characteristics.

fMRI study investigating social expectancy violations (warmth and competence) and neural correlates of social cognition in perceivers. Involves social-related task/perception of others in humans; not a review and likely healthy participants. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition with gaze cues). Includes a healthy younger adult group aged 17–27, meeting the ≥17–65 healthy participant criterion. Task clearly social-related; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

The abstract describes a machine-learning method for multi-view bipartite graph clustering; no fMRI, human participants, or social-related task is mentioned. It does not meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of identity discrimination of faces—this is social perception (Perception/Understanding of Others). Uses healthy adult participants (typical adult sample) and reports task-based fMRI. Abstract lacks exact age range; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

fMRI study of social processing (empathy/sympathy) in a sample of healthy participants aged 7–40, which includes adults within the 17–65 range. The abstract describes task-based fMRI during social-emotional stimuli; sufficient information to include for full-text review to confirm adult-specific data and extract relevant results.

fMRI study using a social rejection (Cyberball) task in healthy participants and reports an adult participant group. Abstract lacks explicit adult age range (17–65 criterion unclear). Include for full-text review to confirm adult ages and eligibility.

fMRI study of dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset), directly addressing social communication and social-related processing in humans. Abstract does not specify participant age or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65) and other inclusion details.

fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (self-, mother-referential tasks and a visual theory-of-mind social attribution task) in human participants. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or confirm they are healthy adults, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This article is a literature review (narrative review) of hallucinogens/entactogens and social cognition, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and lacks primary fMRI data.

fMRI study probing social-cognitive collective memory (medial prefrontal cortex) during recall of WWII displays—addresses social processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults (museum visitors), but ages not specified in abstract. Insufficient detail on exact ages/sample; include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI in a sample of ASD toddlers and comparison groups; no task-based social processing, and participants are toddlers (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria for task fMRI in healthy adults.

The study uses multi-voxel pattern analysis of neural responses to social/affective touch (a social processing task) and likely involves fMRI. However the abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included or participant ages. Due to insufficient information to confirm the healthy adult group, include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Study uses fMRI to examine neural responses to human voices, a form of social communication/perception. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status. Because it addresses social processing but lacks participant details, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of perceiving others' actions (perception/understanding of others), which is a social-related task. Includes a healthy participant group (n=31). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, criteria are likely met; include for full-text review to confirm age range.

fMRI study examining neural representations of honesty and subsequent trust behavior — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant health/ages; insufficient detail to confirm but meets topic and is not a review. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

Uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although behavioral measures of social cognition (emotion/sarcasm recognition) are reported and healthy controls are included, no fMRI was conducted while participants performed a social processing task.

fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing (a social-related task). Title/abstract focus on ASD but likely includes a healthy control group; abstract is truncated and does not report participant ages or explicit healthy group details. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult group (17–65) and task specifics.

Participants are adolescents aged 16–17 years (not adults). Meta-analysis requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65. Although task is social-related, the sample falls outside the adult age range.

fMRI was conducted while participants played the prisoners' dilemma (a social task) and the study includes a healthy control group. The abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear). Not a review; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

This paper is a meta-analysis/review (PubMed search, neurosynth, and resting-state analyses) rather than an original task-based fMRI study. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Although it discusses social cognition among domains, it does not report primary fMRI data from social tasks in healthy adults, so exclude based on abstract.

fMRI was used during an interactive trust game (a social-processing task) and the study included a healthy control group. However, controls are reported as age 13–19 (includes <17), so it is unclear whether the healthy sample meets the review’s 17–65 age criterion. Abstract lacks sufficient age-specific detail — include for full-text review.

Study uses visual color-discrimination task and examines visual gamma/fMRI coupling; it does not investigate social processing, social cognition, or related constructs. Therefore it does not meet the meta-analysis inclusion criterion of a social-related task in fMRI.

The study reports rtfMRI neurofeedback for emotion regulation in healthy adults targeting the hippocampus but does not describe any social-related task or measures of social processing (affiliation, communication, self/other perception). Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement of an fMRI task probing social processing.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing fMRI. Inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, the imaging did not occur during a social task, so exclude.

Study used resting-state fMRI before/after rTMS rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although participants were healthy, no task-based social processing was assessed, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

This is a review/theoretical article summarizing human neuroimaging literature on cerebellar function rather than reporting a primary fMRI experiment. It is therefore a review/meta-analytic-type paper (not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults).

fMRI was performed on 36 healthy adult participants during vocal emotional processing (social communication/perception of others). This is an experimental task addressing social-related processing and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI experiment measured neural responses to photographs of disfigured faces, probing social perception/cognition (empathy, dehumanization). Appears to use healthy adult participants. Meets review objective of social-related fMRI processing. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study directly investigates social interaction processing (dyadic interactions) in humans, fitting the review objective and not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages or confirm healthy adult sample; include for full-text review to verify participant demographics and task specifics.

fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic facial expressions (social communication/perception of others) in a human sample (n=51). Not a review/meta-analysis. Sample appears to be healthy adult participants; task is clearly social-related, meeting inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review.

The study reports fMRI in 78 individuals using a protocol that explicitly includes social perception and reasoning tasks, i.e. social-related processing in humans. It presents group and individual-level data in (presumably) healthy participants, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria; full text can confirm ages and health status.

fMRI study using a social exclusion (virtual ball-tossing) task with 71 female participants. This examines social processing in (presumably) healthy adults and matches the review objective. Ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing controls), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI of social processing, it does not include an adult healthy participant group required by the review.

fMRI data were collected during resting state (no task). The inclusion criteria require functional MRI during a social-related task; thus the study does not meet the task-based fMRI requirement despite involving face/social processing in healthy adults.

This article is a narrative review integrating fMRI and behavioural studies in adolescence rather than an original fMRI study of human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; therefore it should be excluded from the meta-analysis of primary fMRI studies in healthy adults.

fMRI was used while participants viewed stigmatized individuals—a social perception/understanding of others task. Includes healthy young adult group (young and older adults), so meets age criterion. Study investigates social cognition (empathy, regulation) in healthy adults and is not a review.

Participants are adolescents aged 9–17 (no adult group within 17–65). Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample does not include a healthy adult group in the required age range, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Participants are healthy children and adolescents aged 10–17 (no adult sample within 17–65). The meta-analysis requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65, so this study does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are children (ages 7–12), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although fMRI and social/empathy task are relevant, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Participants are typically-developing children (mean age ~10 years), which falls outside the review’s required adult age range (17–65). Although fMRI and social tasks were used, age criterion excludes study.

All participants were children (7–10 years). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65; no adult group is reported, so the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

This publication is a review article (Trends in Cognitive Sciences) summarizing MRI findings in adolescence rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide primary fMRI data in adults.
Study used fMRI in preterm infants (31+6–36+3 weeks PMA) to map sensorimotor/somatosensory cortex. Participants are not adults (17–65) and task is not social processing.

Participants are described as adolescent boys (teens); both patient and healthy control groups are adolescents, not adults in the 17–65 age range required by the review. The abstract gives no indication of healthy adult participants, so it does not meet the population criterion.

Study used functional MRI during a social-evaluation task (self-conscious emotion when believing a peer was watching) and included child, adolescent, and adult participants. This meets the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy participants; adult group presence likely falls within 17–65. Abstract lacks exact age ranges, so full-text review recommended to confirm ages and sample health status.

fMRI study using a social regulation task (hand-holding with friend vs stranger vs alone) performed in adult participants (~24 years). It examines social-affiliative processes in healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study of how expert advice (social influence) affects decision-making; examines social-cognition-related neural correlates. Includes healthy adult participants (18+). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study where healthy participants performed social hierarchy/alliance judgments (social cognition). Not a review. Abstract does not report participants' ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed on age criterion from abstract alone—include for full-text review to verify ages and other details.

Event-related fMRI examining person perception/mentalizing during social expectation violations fits the review objective (social-related processing). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

fMRI study in healthy adults (n=22) using affective/social touch task probing social perception/cognition (CT-targeted touch); directly addresses social processing; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of Black and White faces varying in SES) conducted in 61 healthy White adult participants. Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing face and voice perception tasks (unimodal and bimodal), directly addressing social communication/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults. Age range not specified but participants appear to be healthy adults; full text can confirm ages if needed.

fMRI study examining empathy (perception/understanding of others) — a social-processing task — in human participants. Abstract indicates healthy adult participants and reports neural activations during the task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study 2 uses fMRI to examine neural responses in regions associated with mental-state attribution (mPFC, PCC, temporal poles) while viewing social targets, fitting 'Perception and Understanding of Others'. Human adult participants (heterosexual men reported) are described; not a review. Full text may be needed for exact age range/sample details, so include for full-text review.

Study used event-related fMRI (with EEG) in 14 healthy adults (mean age 29) during perception of others' emotional facial expressions, which is social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). Participants are within the 17–65 age range and healthy. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: Meets all inclusion criteria. The study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adults (n=18, ages ~40) performing an interactive joint-action (leading vs following) task that engages social processing (perception/understanding of others, mentalizing and social networks). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (Leading > Rest, Following > Rest, conjunctions, and whole-group regressions) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster corrections; results are presented as statistical maps, figures, and coordinate tables for the healthy participant group. It is empirical fMRI work (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only), and healthy adult results are reported separately and generalizable. Caveats: small sample and some results reported at a more lenient threshold, but whole-brain task-evoked maps are clearly reported for the healthy group.

Although this is an fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of faces varying by race and status) in a healthy adult sample (N=60, mean age 23.8), the paper’s reported analyses focus on multivariate behavioral PLS and supplemental PLS results. The full text does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables for the healthy/control group. The manuscript refers to an earlier univariate analysis of these data but does not provide univariate whole-brain results within this paper. Because the review requires at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map reported for the healthy group, this study does not meet that inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in a healthy adult sample (N=16; ages 22–34). Participants viewed a 20-min movie excerpt with coded social interactions; analyses used a GLM with second-level, group-level whole-brain voxelwise statistics (F- and t-tests) and voxelwise FWE correction (p<0.05). The paper reports whole-brain contrast maps, cluster tables, and peak coordinates for contrasts (e.g., verbal > non-verbal; contrasts among non-verbal types), clearly derived from the healthy control group. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-group-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social vs nonsocial approach-avoidance task (social positive/negative stimuli) in healthy adult participants (male, mean age 21.35). The sample (N=76 analyzed) falls within the 17–65 range and reports group-level voxelwise task contrasts. Although ROI analyses were emphasized, the paper also states that exploratory whole-brain analyses are reported (P<.05, peak-level corrected, clusters >10 voxels) and presents group-level contrasts (e.g., approach/avoidance, social>nonsocial) derived from the healthy sample. The study therefore provides univariate, task-evoked, group-level whole-brain results from healthy adults and addresses social processing, meeting all inclusion criteria and not violating exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=22, ages within 17–65) investigating mind perception and social attention. The fMRI experiment involved a mind-perception task (social-cognitive construct: perception/understanding of others) performed during scanning. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise parametric analyses with cluster-based correction (FWER p<.05) and tables/coordinates indicating significant clusters (vmPFC and other regions). Although an initial analysis across all runs did not survive correction, the authors report a post hoc whole-brain corrected result (first two runs) and a separate whole-brain parametric analysis relating activation to gaze-cueing behavior that survived correction. Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults investigating social processing.

This is an fMRI study of empathy (perception and understanding of others), using a social task (modified Empathic Accuracy Task) in healthy adults (final fMRI sample N=34, ages 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole‑brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (emotional>neutral, parametric modulation by empathic accuracy, time-series correlations with intensity) using SPM12 and FSL randomise with TFCE FWE correction, and presents significant clusters/peak coordinates. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and provides healthy-group whole-brain task effects generalizable to adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody) in healthy adults (N=22, mean age ~27, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and lists activation locations in the text/figures. It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results (PPIs are reported additionally). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level voxelwise results) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social decision task (control-aversion where another person restricts choices), addressing social cognition/perception of others. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=51, mean age 22) within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates (e.g., right IPL 39 −40 40), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Although connectivity (PPI) analyses are included, the study also provides univariate whole-brain activation maps, so it is not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports original task-based fMRI data using social vs. non-social stimuli (IAPS images) with an explicit social-related manipulation (socialness of scenes) and a valence appraisal task. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=14 analyzed; ages 23–50), meeting the age and healthy-group requirements. Crucially, group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses are reported (social > nonsocial contrast; voxelwise thresholds and FDR correction; conjunction with NeuroSynth map), providing task-evoked whole-brain statistical maps generalizable to the healthy adult group. The paper is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group contrasts, or non-empirical data. Although the independent sample is small (noted by authors), this does not violate inclusion criteria. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (ages 18–34 and 18–30 across experiments). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., social interaction > independent actions) with FDR-corrected significant clusters in the right pSTS/STG in Experiment 1, satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. The task probes social perception/understanding of others. The sample consists of healthy adults and whole-brain results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or non-healthy-only samples) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the study tested healthy adult participants (ages 21–46) and reports group-level, whole-brain task activation maps (one-sample contrasts and corrected FWE results for each orientation group), the experimental paradigm is an erotic sexual-arousal/reward task focused on incentive motivation (ventral striatum) in response to sexual stimuli. The study’s primary constructs concern sexual arousal and orientation rather than social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others). Therefore it does not meet the meta-analysis requirement that the fMRI task probe social-related processing and is excluded.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age 40.4, ages within 17–65) using a social joint-action task (leading/following/mutual haptic interaction) relevant to social cognition (perception/understanding of others, mentalizing, social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and statistical maps (random-effects analyses, voxelwise contrasts with FDR correction and cluster thresholds) with Talairach coordinates and tables of peak activations. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not patient-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study (three datasets, combined N=59 healthy adult participants) that directly probes social-related processing (person knowledge: faces, spoken/written names; and socially relevant concept words). Group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g., social > non-social semantics and social/non-social > non-semantic baseline) are reported with voxelwise thresholds, cluster correction, peak coordinates, and whole-brain figures, clearly derived from the healthy/control participants. The paper therefore provides whole-brain task activation maps from a healthy adult sample and is not limited to ROI-only, resting-state, or between-group-only contrasts. No exclusion criteria appear to be violated based on the provided text. Hence the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (N=36) and the task assesses perception/understanding of others, the reported neuroimaging results are restricted to an a priori vACC region-of-interest with small-volume correction. The paper does not present or describe any unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation maps (only ROI/SVC results are reported). Per the review’s inclusion criteria requiring at least one whole-brain group-level univariate task map, this study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=16, mean age 22.8) using a social-perception task (judging facing/approach of point-light and human-like walkers) addressing social involvement and action understanding. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses (main effects and interactions) with stereotaxic coordinates and FWE-corrected results within predefined masks, which are clearly described as coming from the healthy participant group. Analyses are task-evoked BOLD contrasts (not solely ROI, connectivity, or resting-state). Inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adults, whole-brain group-level univariate results) are met. Although sample size is modest, that does not violate inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI to probe social-related processing (moral dilemmas, kinship, perspective taking) during movie-watching and a separate moral-decision task; (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=30, females aged 19–39), within 17–65; (3) Reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked results: GLM analysis of the moral-dilemma decision task (group one-sample t-tests, cluster correction) and whole-brain inter-subject correlation (ISC) maps with multiple-comparison correction; results and cluster coordinates are described and visualized. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, healthy-group maps clearly reported). Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind) in healthy adult participants (ages within 17–65) and reports ROI-based and MVPA analyses, the full text does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The paper defines individual ROIs using a within-subject localizer (Belief > Photo) and reports ROI/MVPA classification results and between-subject statistics, but no whole-brain, group-level activation maps or coordinate tables for an univariate task contrast are described in the provided content. Because the review’s inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported group-level whole-brain task activation/contrast from the healthy adult sample, this study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using a social task (imitate/observe emotional faces) in healthy adults (initial N=28, ages 18–55; imaging N=20 included in analyses). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: a GLM in SPM8 (group task contrasts referenced and shown in Supplementary Figure 1) and whole-brain voxelwise PLS maps (bootstrap-ratio maps rendered on brain images) linking task-evoked activity to social-cognitive performance. Results are presented at the group level and are clearly generalizable to healthy adults; analyses are not limited to ROIs or to resting-state/seed connectivity only. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria for task-based whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 1) Task: fMRI was used during a social cognition (mentalising/theory-of-mind) task contrasting mentalising vs factual memory, a social-related process. 2) Sample: healthy adult participants were used (Experiment 2: N=17, mean age 22±2.9, within 17–65). 3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain analyses are reported (SPM2 second-level ANOVAs, contrasts such as mentalising>factual and parametric mentalising>parametric factual) with whole-brain corrected thresholds and tabulated/visualized activation maps/coordinates. 4) No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not only between-group contrasts, empirical fMRI data on healthy adults provided). Therefore the study should be included for the meta-analysis.

Empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult samples (study 1: n=41, study 2: n=39; ages 18–24). Tasks probe social-related constructs (self-related processing and mentalizing/social cognition) during article exposure and include established localizers for self and mentalizing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task analyses (exploratory whole-brain searches; thresholded maps and whole-brain tables/clusters reported, multiple comparisons correction detailed) in the healthy samples. Results for healthy participants are presented and generalizable; analyses are not limited to ROI-only or to between-group contrasts. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults with whole-brain activation results.

Study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (final N=25, ages 21–33) during social-related processing (attending to facial aspects: emotion and age — perception/understanding of others). The methods report group-level whole-brain analyses: a random-effects second-level univariate contrast (faces > objects) was computed from the localizer, and whole-brain searchlight (voxelwise) results are reported (SnPM-corrected and/or voxelwise thresholds) identifying regions decoding task and emotional valence. The paper therefore provides task-evoked, group-level whole-brain statistical maps from a healthy adult sample and does not rely exclusively on ROI or resting-state/ connectivity-only analyses. All inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (attribution of emotions/mental states to humans and non-human animals) in healthy adults (N=18, analyzed N=16–17; ages 21–46). The tasks explicitly probe social-related processes (theory of mind/anthropomorphism) via an Explicit Emotion>Expression contrast and an Implicit Face>Scramble contrast. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (conjunctions, contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) and ROI analyses; whole-brain results are described and thresholding/statistics are provided. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy sample are reported separately. The study is empirical and reports task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (empathy for pain) in healthy adults (male participants aged 18–40). The task is explicitly social (empathy/affect sharing, cognitive appraisal). The authors report group-level, univariate, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (INJECTION>QTIP and BIOPSY>QTIP) with family-wise error correction and present peak coordinates from whole-brain analyses (including conjunction results), which constitute whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adult participants. Results for the healthy groups (stress and control, and analyses across participants) are reported separately and are population-level random-effects analyses. The study does not fall under any exclusion criteria (it is empirical, task-based, includes healthy adults, and provides whole-brain activation results rather than only ROI or connectivity-only findings). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI during a social face-encoding/recognition paradigm in healthy adults (including a young adult subgroup 20–31 years), all reported imaging analyses focus on an a priori amygdala ROI (extraction of average parameter estimates). The paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps, whole-brain contrasts, or coordinate tables generalizable to the healthy adult group. Therefore it fails the required 'whole-brain evidence' inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

The study uses task-based fMRI with a social-related paradigm (Face Matching Task assessing perception of others’ emotional/facial expressions). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=10, mean age 25), within the 17–65 range and reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (neutral+fear > control; fear > neutral; fear > neutral+control) with second-level one-sample t-tests and tabulated/figure results in the Supplementary Material. It is not ROI-only, not solely seed/connectivity or resting-state, and not a non-empirical paper. Although the sample is small, all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma), a social-related task targeting perception/processing of others and social reward. Sample: healthy adult participants (final N=18, mean age ~21), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., CC versus other outcomes) with reported cluster-level FWE-corrected thresholds and MNI coordinates in tables/text and whole-brain figures. ROI analyses are present but supplemented by whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within age range, empirical fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=24, ages 19–31) investigating social processing (cooperation vs competition, self/other judgments). The task is explicitly social and relevant to perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports task-evoked, group-level univariate GLM analyses identifying whole-brain activations (e.g., pgACC and area 9) and links these to behavior; although ROI analyses follow, initial region identification used whole-brain voxelwise contrasts and GLMs. Results are reported at the group level and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, participants within age range, empirical fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study probing attachment-related social processing (attachment vs matched neutral scenes), which falls squarely within the review’s social-related constructs (Affiliation/Attachment, social cognition). Sample includes N=25 healthy adults (age 19–26), satisfying the age and healthy-group criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., attachment vs. neutral; dyadic/monadic interactions) with voxelwise coordinate tables and cluster-level corrected statistics and figures, clearly attributable to the healthy/control group. It is not ROI-only, resting-state, connectivity-only, nor non-empirical. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (pilot N=10, main N=15; college/community adults ≥18). Tasks are socially relevant (Prisoner’s Dilemma, Ultimatum/Welfare games; socialization manipulations: Acquaintance vs Random Individual/Human vs Computer) addressing social cognition, affiliation, and perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (first/second/third-level GLM in FSL and SPM12), thresholded voxelwise/cluster-corrected maps with peak coordinates and statistics (Z/T values) and FWE/corrected tables/figures. It also reports behavioral results for the healthy groups separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only results (although PPI is reported, whole-brain activations are primary). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others’ actions in emotional contexts—anger vs. joy). Sample includes 20 healthy adult participants (ages 23–33), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (e.g., main effects and contrasts such as angry session > joyful session and grasping observation effects) with corrected statistics and tables/coordinates, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only findings. Although additional ROI, PPI, and DCM analyses are presented, whole-brain maps/contrasts for the healthy group are clearly reported and generalizable. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study used fMRI in healthy adult participants and includes social-related tasks (theory-of-mind and attribution-of-attention), it does not report a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group. The main task analyses use localized group-level ICA restricted to a TPJ ROI and regression of IC time courses, with IC spatial maps thresholded within the TPJ mask; task-related results are presented as ROI/ICA-derived component maps and seed-to-voxel connectivity maps. These do not constitute an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise task activation map or conventional whole-brain GLM contrast generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level whole-brain task activation map, the study must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI during a social decision-making task (Ultimatum Game) probing affiliation/cooperation; sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=51, ages ~31, within 17–65) with results reported separately for healthy groups; reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects task analyses with voxelwise results and coordinates (e.g., anterior insula, septal region) including corrected statistics and tables/figures. Not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (charitable giving manipulating empathy and perspective taking) in healthy adults (N=33, ages 20–34). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate analyses (multiple GLMs and random-effects t tests, reported with voxelwise FWE correction and coordinate tables/figures), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Tasks explicitly probe social processes (empathy, perspective taking) and results include whole-brain statistical maps/cluster coordinates. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=15 males, mean age 22.3) using a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing retaliation/ social processing. The authors report group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (decision and outcome phases), with Talairach coordinates and statistical maps described in the text and figures, and parametric whole-brain results. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball ball-toss task (a social interaction paradigm) in healthy adult participants (final N=31, mean age ~21, within 17–65 range). The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., ball-toss [high-frequency – normal-frequency] > button-press [high-frequency – normal-frequency]) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates (ventral striatum, precuneus) provided. Results are univariate, generalizable to the healthy group, and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (person perception and person knowledge/ToM) in healthy adults. Sample: 21 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.6), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names, Traits>Neutral, and the interaction) with coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected results, figures, and supplementary tables. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the manuscript also provides univariate whole-brain activation maps from the healthy/control group, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and results are reported for the healthy adult group). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20 scanned; mean age 25.7) using a social-related task (guilt memories vs hypothetical social scenarios). The paper reports group-level, within-group voxelwise task contrasts (guilt memory > neutral memory; guilt hypothetical > neutral hypothetical; guilt memory > guilt hypothetical) with whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001, cluster extent) and reported peak coordinates/figures; SPM8 GLM group analyses and whole-brain results are explicitly described. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy subjects. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This conference proof-of-concept study reports EEG–fMRI correlation analysis and a real-time fMRI neurofeedback approach targeting the right pSTS. The abstract and available full-text information describe ROI-targeting and correlation features but do not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult group. Participant details and explicit healthy-group whole-brain results are not reported; the focus is on method development/ROI correlation rather than whole-brain task activation. Therefore it fails the required inclusion criterion of reporting at least one group-level whole-brain task activation map and appears to be an ROI/methods-oriented conference paper (non-qualifying).

Insufficient evidence in full text to meet inclusion criteria. The abstract/record does not report participant demographics or confirm a healthy adult sample (age 17–65), and provides no details on group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (voxelwise results or coordinates/figures) for a healthy/control group. It appears to be a brief conference paper/abstract, and no whole-brain activation tables or explicit healthy-group maps are described. Because at least one clearly identified whole-brain, group-level task activation in healthy adults is required, and that criterion is not met (and ROI/connectivity-only or resting-state–only results are excluded), this study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (comprehension of speech acts — Naming vs Requesting), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=18 analysed; ages 18–41). The authors report group-level, random-effects whole-brain voxelwise analyses (e.g., Request > Naming and Words > Faces) with FDR correction (p<0.05) and describe whole-brain results in the text and figures/tables. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and is empirical with original task-evoked activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (agency vs. communion) using a task-based valence classification in healthy adult participants (N=42; ages 18–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (GLM contrasts, conjunctions) with cluster correction (AlphaSim) and presents results in figures/tables (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Healthy adult results are reported separately and generalizable (not limited to a special subgroup). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=28; ages 30–50) that explicitly examines self-referential and social stimulus processing using a task with social vs non-social pictures. Analysis used whole-brain, voxelwise GLM at the group level (ANOVA) with reported contrasts, conjunctions, cluster-corrected maps and coordinate tables (FDR p<0.05, k≥20). Results for the healthy sample are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=15, males, mean age 23.6) using a social task (viewing aggressive dyadic interactions with attention manipulated to aggressor vs victim). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM analyses and voxelwise contrasts (e.g., focus-on-aggressor vs focus-on-victim) with cluster-size correction and reports anatomical activations (amygdala, ACC, EBA, STS, etc.), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only, includes task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults, and does not fall under any exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) using validated ToM vs random-motion animations in healthy adult participants (N=20; age range 24–64, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (ToM > R, ToM > Baseline, R > Baseline) with stated voxelwise and cluster-level thresholds and lists significant activations (including tables/figures). Results are clearly reported for the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=37, age range 18–25) examining the neural basis of the urge to imitate (a social-related process linked to perception/understanding of others and social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (parametric modulation and one-sample t-tests) with corrected cluster thresholds and peak coordinates, as well as figures/tables describing whole-brain results.
