Although connectivity (PPI) is also reported, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy adult group are clearly presented and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20, ages 19–31) using multiple social-cognition tasks (theory of mind, face perception, biological motion, voice perception, and language). The paper reports univariate GLM analyses and mixed-effects group-level activation maps and provides peak coordinates in MNI space for task contrasts. Although many STS-focused analyses used an STS mask, the methods and results include group-level voxelwise activation maps/peak coordinates that are clearly reported for the healthy sample and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met (social task, healthy adult sample, group-level univariate whole-brain results reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of face-to-face social interaction (eye contact), a social-related task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Participants: 19 pairs (38 healthy adults), ages 18–33 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM results (task A and B), paired t-tests to identify exogenous/endogenous systems, inference thresholds (Z>2.3, p<0.05) and cluster tables with atlas labels, voxel sizes and MNI152 coordinates. Results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and probabilistic atlas label distributions, not ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Healthy adult group results are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, clinical-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an original, empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=34, ages 21–32). The task is explicitly social (sender–receiver strategic interaction; deception, theory-of-mind, social cognition). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., simple deception vs. truth, sophisticated deception vs. truth, truth vs. deception) with Bayesian second-level posterior probability maps and tables of coordinates for activations across the whole brain. Analyses are task-evoked, not solely ROI- or connectivity-based, and results for the healthy adult group are reported and generalizable. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The provided full-text is a brief conference abstract that does not report essential information required by the inclusion criteria. While it describes dyadic fMRI and a derived ‘neural basis,’ it does not provide participant details (sample size, ages) to confirm a healthy adult group (17–65). The text also does not present or describe any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or clear within-group contrasts for a healthy/control group—only high-level, data-driven findings are mentioned. Because key inclusion criteria (clear healthy adult sample details and explicit whole-brain task-activation results) are not met or cannot be verified from the abstract, the study must be excluded. If the full conference paper or a companion full article (e.g., the 2015 PLoS One paper) provides the missing details, that full report could be re-evaluated for inclusion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: The study uses task-based fMRI during an experimentally controlled social communication task (interactive communicative game) in healthy adult participants (54 right-handed males, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects, cluster-level inference with familywise error correction and whole-brain searches), with reported coordinates, figures, and detailed methods. Although the paper also includes connectivity/coherence analyses, it clearly presents whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and healthy adults are within the 17–65 range). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (formation of social ties/other-regarding preferences) using a repeated public-good game in healthy adult participants (scanned group n=25, mean age ~22.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM) with cluster-wise FWE correction and MNI coordinates for multiple task-evoked effects (parametric modulation by social tie, impulse, contribution magnitude), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although PPI connectivity is also reported, the study additionally provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps and coordinate tables for the healthy control group (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not between-group-only). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: task manipulates social sharing (together vs alone) while viewing emotional/neutral images, probing affiliation-related processes. The sample includes healthy adults (age 20–33); fMRI analyses were performed on a within-group healthy sample (n=26 after exclusions). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate whole-brain analyses (random-effects GLM; voxelwise threshold p<0.001 with cluster-level whole-brain correction via AlphaSim) and lists whole-brain activations (e.g., DLPFC, precuneus) in addition to ROI results. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (fMRI task of social-related processing, healthy adult sample, and reported whole-brain task-evoked group results). Note: sample is female-only and modest fMRI N, but still within 17–65 and reported separately for healthy group.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (perception of biological motion vs scrambled motion), tested healthy adult participants (N=26, ages 18–39), and reports within-group task-evoked analyses. Importantly, the authors conducted and report whole-brain analyses (biological-motion selectivity correlated with social-network measures) with correction for multiple comparisons and identification of a significant cluster in right pSTS/TPJ. Results are described in text and supplemental figures/tables, satisfying the requirement for a group-level, univariate whole-brain task effect generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study using social stimuli (traffic-awareness campaign videos designed to induce empathy) addressing socio-emotional processing (empathy, mentalising). Sample: 20 healthy adult participants (all right-handed males, ages 20–28), meeting the 17–65 healthy adult criterion and reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (CV > NV contrast) using random-effects one-sample t-tests with FWE-corrected voxelwise results and cluster peaks/coordinates summarized in tables and figures. Therefore it provides a healthy-group, whole-brain task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor is it non-empirical. Accordingly, it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this fMRI study used a social task (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants and reports group-level task contrasts, the second-level voxelwise analyses were explicitly conducted within a restricted composite ROI mask (16 bilateral regions created with wfu_pickatlas). All reported statistical inference and multiple-comparisons correction were performed within that mask, not across the whole brain. Therefore the paper does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation map generalizable to healthy adults, which fails the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion. Other inclusion criteria (healthy adult sample; social task; group-level contrasts) are met, but the lack of whole-brain results warrants exclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social feedback processing (self/other trait evaluations) in healthy adult participants (German and Chinese groups). The task is explicitly social (perception/understanding of self and others; face-to-face interaction and peer feedback). Group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results are reported (e.g., main effects and interactions for feedback onset, parametric modulators for reward- and comparison-related components) with voxelwise FWE-corrected clusters and coordinates presented in tables/figures. Healthy adult results are reported and generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup), and analyses are not ROI-only nor connectivity-only. Thus the paper meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (conceptual and agentic self-referential recollection). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=18; ages 19–29). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task analyses (conjunctions and contrasts), including whole-brain FWE-corrected results and coordinate tables, not limited to ROI-only findings. Results are clearly reported for the healthy control group and generalizable within the healthy adult range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social distance: participants compared friends vs acquaintances) in a healthy adult sample (N=15, ages 20–28). The authors performed and report group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (paired t-tests and a conjunction analysis comparing sooner/later, closer/farther, more/less familiar), even though these univariate contrasts yielded no FDR-corrected positive voxels; the methods and results clearly describe whole-brain task-evoked group maps. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, includes no clinical group confounds, and reports behavioral and imaging results for healthy adults. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social communication/empathy in healthy adults (n=27, mean age 34.07, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate whole-brain analyses and contrasts (e.g., E > N, modality-specific contrasts and conjunction analyses) with reported activations (FFG, AC, AG, dmPFC) and coordinates/figures, not limited to ROI-only results. Although additional connectivity (DCM) and ROI/FIR analyses are included, whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy sample are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognitive processing (attribute framing, self- and reflected-perspective evaluations), using healthy adult participants (N=19 after exclusions; ages 19–41). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses and multiple within-group contrasts (e.g., task vs control, positive vs negative frame, frame-inconsistent vs frame-consistent) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster corrections; coordinates and activation maps are described. Results are reported for the healthy adult sample (no clinical group confounds). The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and whole-brain task-evoked group-level results). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply.

This paper is a review/theoretical article (Japanese review with abstract) describing concepts and summarizing findings; it does not present original empirical fMRI data, participant/sample details, or report any group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for healthy adults. Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria requiring original fMRI task data and whole-brain results and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers without original fMRI data.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (n=26, age mean 26, within 17–65). The task is social-related (third-party punishment; mentalizing/attribution of others’ intentions), fitting the review’s constructs (perception/understanding of others). Analyses include group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise GLM results with FDR-corrected thresholds and reported peak coordinates (e.g., right TPJ, right anterior insula), which constitute univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The paper does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor non-empirical methods. Healthy-group results are reported separately and clearly. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (interns N=19, producers N=79; mean ages ≈20.5 within 17–65). The task probes social communication/understanding (message propagation, mentalizing, persuasion). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (task > rest and parametric modulators) with reported voxelwise results and coordinates (threshold p < .005, k = 60; Table 1 and figures), identifying reward and mentalizing regions (VS, TPJ, DMPFC). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group effects are clearly described and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state only, not ROI-only, includes healthy adults). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and evaluation of different laughter types; social communication and mentalizing). Sample: 18 healthy adult participants (mean age 26), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (second-level random-effects contrasts such as CSL>TIC and CAT>COU) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction; results are described in text, figures and tables. Although connectivity/PPI analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate activation maps for the healthy adult group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not clinical-only). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=15, mean age 22.3) that includes a social-related task (social-closeness judgments about friends) and a famous-face task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with corrected voxelwise/cluster thresholds and provides Talairach coordinates and maps for activations (e.g., ATL, FFA, MPFC, OFC). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, includes univariate task-evoked whole-brain contrasts for the healthy sample, and thus meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

Meets inclusion criteria: fMRI task probing social cognition (interactive vs observational social processing) in healthy adults (N=22, mean age 25). Group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses were conducted (three-way repeated-measures RFX whole-brain ANOVA with one-sample t-tests; p<0.05 FWE reported), and results are reported for the healthy participant group. Although hypothesis testing used ROI (small-volume) corrections for key contrasts, the paper also reports exploratory whole-brain findings (e.g., V1) and provides voxelwise results/coordinates and thresholds. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and data are group-level and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) investigating action observation/execution and induced mirror representations—constructs clearly related to perception and understanding of others (social cognition). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (threshold p<0.001 uncorrected, cluster extent=4 voxels) in addition to ROI analyses, with peak coordinates and statistical maps described for Sessions 1 and 2. All inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, fMRI during social-related task, and whole-brain group-level results). No exclusion criteria are violated (not limited to ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes whole-brain healthy-group effects).

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding; why/how task) in healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–32). The authors report group-level, random-effects voxelwise analyses using SPM (conjunctions, F contrasts) and provide cluster-wise corrected activations with MNI coordinates (Table 1) for mirror-neuron and mentalizing systems. The text explicitly states that details about the mask and whole-brain results are provided in the Supplemental Methods, and whole-brain/univariate task effects are reported as voxelwise contrasts rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore the study meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) group-level univariate voxelwise whole-brain results (coordinates/tables and supplementary whole-brain results). It does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes task activations for healthy group).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception using naturalistic audiovisual stimuli in healthy adults (N=19; ages 21–34). The authors report group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate GLM analyses (one-sample t-tests), thresholded voxelwise (p<0.05 FDR) and present whole-brain statistical maps, coordinates, and figures for multiple social vs. non-social contrasts and individual social-feature effects. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study is neither ROI-only nor resting-state/connectivity-only; it provides task-evoked, whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: 27 right-handed healthy participants (ages mean ~25, within 17–65). The task involved viewing naturalistic social interaction pictures (cooperative vs affective) during event-related fMRI. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (direct contrasts, conjunctions) with FWE-corrected thresholds and detailed coordinates/figures for healthy participants. Whole-brain results (e.g., cooperative vs affective, interaction effects) are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes an appropriate healthy adult group). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of valenced self- and other-referential processing (VV-SORP-T), directly addressing perception/understanding of self (a social-related construct). Sample comprises 20 healthy adult women aged 18–52 (within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., S-N vs fixation, S-P vs fixation, S-N vs S-P, S-N vs O-N, S-P vs O-P) with voxel-wise thresholds and cluster reporting, tables/figures, and small-volume corrected ROI follow-ups — not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (in-group/out-group action perception) using healthy adult participants (male, ages 17–43). The task is social (team membership, perception/understanding of others) and uses task-evoked whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses reported at group level (contrasts such as action vs fixation and own vs other; cluster-level PFWE < 0.05 with MNI coordinates provided). Results for the healthy control group are reported and generalizable within the sample. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and reports whole-brain activation maps; thus it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=19 males, age 18–51) using an emotional prosody comprehension task that explicitly includes complex/social emotions (pride, guilt) involving inference about others—directly relevant to social communication and perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses conducted in SPM8 with contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple) and corrected cluster-wise results (p<0.05), with activated regions and coordinates described. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor between-group-only. All inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social decision-making (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (male, ages 23–28). The task is social-related (perception/evaluation of offers, social interaction). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain analyses: an offline whole-brain classification across subjects with discriminating volumes/regions reported (voxel-level weights transformed into voxel space and permutation-derived p-values, with reported discriminating volumes and coordinates), and leave-one-subject-out cross-subject validation. Results are not ROI-only and are generalizable to the healthy adult group. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain voxelwise group-level results). Note: primary online method was ROI-based RVM, but the offline whole-brain SVM analyses provide the required whole-brain evidence.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion via Cyberball) in healthy adults (final sample n=20, ages ~25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion), with statistical thresholds, cluster-level correction, and tables/figures of activations. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate results for the healthy adult sample are clearly presented and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity only, participants are within 17–65 and results are reported for the healthy group). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study reports task-based fMRI of observing virtual social interactions (a clear social-related task). Data come from a group of healthy participants (n=15) with informed consent and MRI screening. Imaging used whole-brain EPI acquisition with full-brain coverage, and the paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (social interaction vs. no-interaction) with activation maps and t-values described for typical social-cognition regions (STS, mPFC, amygdala). Analysis used standard SPM preprocessing/GLM reporting. These elements satisfy the review’s inclusion criteria. Minor uncertainty: the excerpt does not explicitly state participant ages (17–65), but recruitment and consent language and typical JoVE adult protocols imply healthy adults; confidence downgraded slightly for that missing explicit age range.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception/understanding of social interaction from point-light displays), matching the review’s constructs. Participants are healthy adults (N=14, mean age 29.4), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses (one-sample t-test) of the SI>NSI contrast, with FDR-corrected threshold (p<0.05) and cluster reporting—i.e., univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study (n=98 healthy adults, mean age 20.7) that uses task-evoked functional MRI during social cognition tasks (judgments about self, friends, and strangers across four experiments). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., self > other, friends > strangers) with thresholded statistical maps and whole-brain analyses described in the text and figures (p<0.001 uncorrected). Healthy adult results are reported separately and generalizable to the target population. The study is not ROI-only, is not resting-state-only, and provides appropriate whole-brain task activation maps, satisfying all inclusion criteria.

Although this fMRI study used a social communicative task (charades) in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age ~27.5), the primary reported results are between-brain Granger-causality maps (an effective/connectivity analysis). The paper does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map (main effect or within-group contrast) for the healthy group within this article—the traditional GLM activation results are described as having been published previously (ref. 33) and the in-paper GLM using motion-energy produced no significant whole-brain activations. Because the study reports only effective/connectivity analyses here without an accompanying univariate whole-brain task activation map, it fails the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and meets the explicit exclusion criterion for connectivity-only papers.

This study uses task-based functional MRI probing social-related processing (perception of non-verbal vocalizations and accompanying facial movements), satisfying the social-communication/social-perception construct. The fMRI sample consists of healthy adults (10 right-handed males, ages 24–37), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (voxel-by-voxel parametric t-tests, contrasts versus rest and AV versus AUD+VIS, cluster-size correction with AlphaSim, and group activation maps/coordinates), providing univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. It does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (empathy/perception and understanding of others) using video stimuli of others in pain. Sample: 43 healthy adult participants (mean age 26.7), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, mass-univariate task contrasts (e.g., genuine pain – no pain; pretended pain – no pain) with voxelwise thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents whole-brain activation maps and regression analyses—i.e., not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Healthy-group results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/monitoring of others’ pupillary changes—social communication/perception of others). Sample: 14 healthy adult participants (mean age 22), within the 17–65 range, with no clinical groups reported. Imaging: group-level, second-level random-effects whole-brain analyses are reported (main effects and interactions), with whole-brain corrected cluster thresholds and voxelwise results described; coordinates and statistical maps are reported for group task effects. The paper is empirical and reports task-evoked, univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not limited to out-of-range ages). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, ages 22–37) using a social-related auditory task (perception/mentalizing about one vs. two walkers). Group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts are reported (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST; STEP1 – NOISE1; STEP2 – NOISE2), with statistical thresholds and Talairach coordinates/activation maps provided. The sample is within the 17–65 age range. The study reports whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults and is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (observation of social vs. individual actions; gaze modulation) in healthy adult participants (N=17, mean age 26, range within 17–65). The paper reports second-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (main effects and interaction), thresholded maps (p<.001 uncorrected) with cluster extents and peak coordinates and figures demonstrating SPM activations (dMPFC, IFG, pSTS, amygdala, etc.). Results are reported for the healthy group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, task-based, and provides whole-brain group-level activation maps/coordinates. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; not connectivity-only; not between-group-only; participants are within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This paper reports an event-related fMRI study of social processing (perception of socially relevant vs. arbitrary facial expressions) in healthy adult participants (N=17, right-handed males, mean age 25.9). It presents group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects analyses (SPM5 ANOVA; voxelwise contrasts with reported stereotactic coordinates and figures/tables) testing the main effect of social interaction in a specific FIR time bin. Results include voxelwise activation maps and coordinate tables (e.g., precentral gyrus, posterior cingulate, hippocampus, midbrain), not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or patient-only contrasts. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level univariate results).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=13, ages 22–38) using a theory-of-mind (social cognition) task (cooperation, deception, cooperation/deception). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects analyses (ToM conditions vs non-ToM) and further direct contrasts between conditions; activation peaks and coordinates are provided. Although ROIs were used for follow-up contrasts, an initial whole-brain one-sample t-test identifying ToM-relevant clusters is explicitly reported, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps from a healthy adult group. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) in (presumably) healthy adult participants. The paper reports group-level task contrasts yielding activations across medial prefrontal cortex (ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, left dorsal MPFC interaction), which indicates whole-brain, univariate voxelwise results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The task clearly probes social-related constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not limited to non-adult sample, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults. Participants were healthy undergraduate adults (mean age 19.5), and analyses used whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (subtracting fixation and 3-versus-1 contrasts) with random-effects group analyses and reported Talairach coordinates for activations (mPFC, insula, amygdala). The task probes perception/understanding of others (emotional appraisal of social groups), fitting the review’s social-related constructs. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps and coordinate tables are clearly reported and generalizable to a healthy adult sample. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social gaze processing in healthy adults (young adults). The task is social-related (mutual vs. averted gaze). The paper reports group-level voxelwise (whole-brain) analyses and t-statistic activation maps averaged across subjects (voxel-based maps shown and described), in addition to ROI analyses. Participants are healthy adults (results for healthy group are reported). The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task fMRI, healthy adult sample, whole-brain univariate group maps). Note: sample size is small and some analyses used fixed-effects group averaging, which may limit generalizability, but this does not violate inclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adult subjects (perception of ingroup/outgroup faces), the full text/abstract indicates findings were driven by a region-of-interest (amygdala) analysis (“A region of interest (ROI)-based analysis of these voxels revealed a significant interaction”). The paper does not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or coordinates/tables that are clearly generalizable to the healthy adult group. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain voxelwise healthy-group task contrast and the study appears to report ROI-based results without clear whole-brain statistical maps, it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using a task that directly probes social interaction recognition (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8 within the 17–65 range) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (SI > NM) with peak- and cluster-level statistics and FWE correction, and describes activations for the adult group (tables/figures and text). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and provides generalizable healthy adult task activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study including a healthy adult group (N=19, ages 22–31). The task probes social-related processing (direct self, direct other, and reflected social self-evaluations from a best friend’s perspective), which maps to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Other’ and peer social processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8; voxel-wise thresholding with AlphaSim FWE correction) and provides cluster coordinates (e.g., bilateral ventral striatum: [−12 21 −6], [27 30 3]) and supplementary adult-specific results, satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, adult subgroup within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this fMRI study examined social-relevant natural touch in healthy adult participants (N=8, ages 22–39) and reports group-level ICA spatial maps and component time courses linked to touch and social-cognition regions, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM main effect or within-group contrast SPM/coordinate table). The analyses are based on ICA decomposition and component time-course comparisons rather than voxelwise task activation contrasts. Per the exclusion criteria, studies reporting only ICA/connectivity-type analyses without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (gender classification from faces), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Sample comprises healthy adults (n=15 analyzed, ages 19–42) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxel-wise analyses (random-effects GLM; contrast gender-different > gender-same) with cluster-corrected thresholds and reports activated regions and coordinates. Although ROI analyses are also performed, the presence of whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group satisfies the inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated (not connectivity-only, not patient-only, empirical fMRI data reported).

This study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult group (n=22; ages 19–35) using affective (CT-targeted) tactile stimulation, a social/affiliative sensory paradigm relevant to social processing. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM analyses are reported for adults (contrasts Arm > Rest and Palm > Rest), with thresholding, cluster correction, figures and tables of peak coordinates described. The adult results are presented separately from child/adolescent groups and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, adult sample within 17–65). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related process. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (ages 19–24), with group-level analyses reported for the healthy sample. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Morph 50% self vs. friend) with coordinates and statistical thresholds (MPFC, PCC, precuneus) and corrected cluster-level inference, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study also includes ROI analyses but crucially provides univariate whole-brain results for the healthy group. It does not rely solely on connectivity or clinical groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: study uses task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (direct and reflected self-appraisals — perception/understanding of self and others). Includes a healthy adult sample (N=12, ages 22.6–30.4) with results reported separately from adolescent data. Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for adults (one-sample t tests vs. rest, conjunction analyses, ANOVAs, and between-condition contrasts) with thresholding and cluster correction described, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. Healthy-group whole-brain activations are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of prosody perception and production, which falls under social communication and perception/understanding of others. Sample: 19 healthy adult native-English speakers (ages 18–58), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., “happy–neutral” and “question–neutral”) thresholded at p<0.05 FDR with cluster extent, and lists activated regions (with supplementary materials for full results). It also reports whole-brain group-level regression analyses correlating neural activity with empathy measures (reported maps and clusters). Analyses are univariate, task-evoked, and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=15, mean age 24.8) that investigates face individuation — a form of perception/understanding of others, which fits the social-related constructs. The paper reports task-evoked, group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (repeated-measures ANOVA on peak HRF responses with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-size correction; whole-brain results described and illustrated in figures/tables and supplementary material), not only ROI findings. The healthy adult group results are reported separately and are generalizable to typical adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social/empathic processing and reports whole-brain, voxelwise results, the sample is a mixed developmental cohort (ages 7–40) and analyses are reported for the combined sample and age-related correlations. The review requires at least one group of healthy adults (17–65) reported separately or whole-brain results clearly generalizable to healthy adults. This paper does not present a stand-alone adult-group whole-brain task activation map (results are pooled across children, adolescents, and adults), so the reported group-level maps are not specific or generalizable to a healthy adult population. Therefore it does not meet the sample-specific inclusion criterion for this adult-focused meta-analysis.

While the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants and addresses social processing (dynamic facial-expression perception), the reported analyses are predominantly ROI-based using small-volume correction (amygdala, insula, striatum, OFC). The paper does not clearly present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map generalizable to healthy adults; reported effects and conjunctions are based on ROI/SVC analyses. Because the meta-analysis requires at least one univariate whole-brain group-level task map (not limited to ROI-only results), this study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of collective/social memory and schema processing implicating social-cognitive constructs (collective meaning, social knowledge, mentalizing) and the dmPFC/vmPFC. Sample: 24 healthy adults aged 22–39 — meets the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain searchlight results (TFCE-corrected permutation tests; Extended Data Fig. 1) linking neural patterns to the collective-schema model, providing whole-brain statistical maps beyond ROI-only analyses. The task probes social-related processing (representation of collective/social frameworks during memory recall) and the analyses include group-level voxelwise inferences generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (observation of interpersonal social touch). It includes a healthy adult control group (NT; n=21) reported separately alongside an ASD group. The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (social vs. non-social touch) with mean group effects and MNI coordinates presented in the main/supplementary materials (e.g., Figure S2 and Table S2), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group task-evoked results. Although a clinical group is present, results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based functional MRI of action observation (perception/understanding of others), a social-related construct. It includes healthy adult participants (Experiments 1–4: total N=79 healthy adults; age-matched controls in Experiment 5), and presents group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; Sleeve/NoSleeve contrasts) with statistical maps and thresholds described and visualized. Healthy-group results are reported separately from patient (SCA6) data. The paper provides voxelwise whole-brain GLM results and thresholded maps/generalizable healthy-group effects, satisfying all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (trust, honesty, formation of trustworthiness impressions — perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=31; mean age 24.3), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (multiple GLMs, voxel-level and cluster-level FWE-corrected contrasts, coordinates and tables) and whole-brain MVPA/searchlight results; findings are clearly reported for the healthy group. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social processing (dynamic facial-expression perception) and includes a healthy adult control group (TD adults, mean age 24.2), it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. The paper’s primary activation results are ROI-based (MANCOVA on predefined social ROIs) and subsequent DCM effective-connectivity analyses. The authors state they conducted whole-brain analyses but report no significant whole-brain activations (and provide no tables/coordinates or figures of a healthy-group task effect). Because qualifying whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results for the healthy group are not presented, the study fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence and must be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (prisoners' dilemma). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 18–50) with results reported separately. The manuscript provides group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation analyses: one-sample t-tests and reported significant activations for controls (e.g., right fusiform gyrus, right superior frontal gyrus, left insula, left superior temporal gyrus) and whole-brain contrasts/ANOVA results, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study sample consists of adolescent males age 13–19 (controls and patients); no separate healthy adult (age 17–65) group or subgroup results are reported. Although whole-brain task activation is reported, it is not presented as a group-level, unmasked healthy adult task map generalizable to adults. Therefore the study fails the sample criterion (healthy adult group) required for inclusion, and thus must be excluded.

Although the study uses task-evoked fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=36, ages 20–35) and addresses vocal emotional processing (a form of social communication), it does not report any group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps or coordinate tables/generalizable voxelwise contrasts for the healthy group. The paper presents ROI-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical/network analyses (Power-264 atlas, OMST filtering, FC metrics) rather than whole-brain voxelwise activation results. This fails the explicit inclusion requirement for at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map, so the study must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task involved social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; implicit bias and responses to facial disfigurement). Sample includes a healthy adult group (N=31, ages 18–35) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (pre- vs post-treatment faces) with familywise-error correction and cluster thresholds; results are described in text, figures, and tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not restricted-age subgroup only). Therefore eligible for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–35) investigating social interaction perception using task paradigms (viewing dyadic and alone interaction videos) during fMRI. The study reports whole-brain GLM estimation and group-level whole-brain analyses for functional localizers (interaction > scrambled, bodies > objects, faces > objects, mentalizing > pain) used to define ROIs and provides whole-brain searchlight results; these constitute group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain analyses in a healthy sample. The task is clearly social (perception/understanding of others, social interaction). No exclusion criteria apply (not an ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only paper, healthy adults included and reported). Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (cyberball social exclusion) in healthy adult participants (N=71 females, age 21.7 ± 2.3), meeting the sample criterion (healthy adults 17–65). The study reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (initial whole-brain threshold p<0.001 uncorrected with clusters surviving FWE correction via small-volume correction) and provides peak coordinates and statistical maps for group-level contrasts. The task probes social-affiliation/ostracism and results are reported at the group level for healthy participants (within- and between-group contrasts across healthy subgroups). Although the sample is female-only (limits generalizability), the paper reports whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and thus satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a socioemotional Face Processing Task (fearful vs. neutral faces) targeting social cognition/empathy. Sample: 49 healthy adults (ages 18–33), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (F > N and N > F contrasts) with TFCE/FWE correction, coordinates, figures and exploratory whole-brain analyses clearly attributed to the healthy group. It also includes ROI and connectivity analyses, but not exclusively; whole-brain activation maps are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and examines face perception (a social-related process), the full text presents analyses focused on ROI-based multivariate pattern analyses (MVPA) and regression of behavioral models onto ROI/probabilistic visual-field masks. The paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., a whole-brain GLM contrast) for the healthy/control group in the main text or figures/tables described; instead results are reported for predefined ROIs and probabilistic visual field regions. Therefore it fails the review’s requirement for at least one clearly reported whole-brain univariate task activation map and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact), using a task probing social communication/attention. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (initial N=34; fMRI analyses reported on 30 participants; mean age ~21.7, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY; LIVE and REPLAY > REST) analyzed with random-effects GLM, cluster-level FWE correction, and tables/figures of significant clusters. Although connectivity and interbrain synchronization analyses are also reported, the study clearly includes whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study in 44 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4) using a social interactive task (pattern game) manipulating cooperation/competition and turn-based vs concurrent interaction. The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction and present cluster-level results and t-maps/coordinates for contrasts among conditions, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Sample falls within 17–65 and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (trustworthiness/fear appraisal of faces). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=17; ages 18–45) with results reported separately alongside a BPD group. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (group-level mixed-effects analyses, task contrasts such as trustworthiness>fearfulness and fearfulness>trustworthiness) and provides peak coordinates and cluster results (e.g., MNI peaks, Supplementary Tables), not only ROI findings. Whole-brain contrasts and group comparisons are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. It does not violate exclusion criteria (not limited to ROI-only, not only connectivity, includes healthy adult whole-brain maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (participants aged 18–22). The task is social (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma; assesses responses to cooperation/defection—perception/understanding of others, social interaction). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM; cluster-based thresholding, Z-statistics, reported clusters/tables and figures) for healthy participants and also reports ROI analyses. Results for healthy/control groups are clearly described and generalizable within the adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task-evoked maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma probing cooperation/trust), enrolled healthy adult participants (N=20 males, age range 21–37), and reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked group-level results (one-sample t-tests, flexible factorial analyses; FWE cluster-corrected maps and tables of activations). Healthy-group effects are reported and generalized to the healthy sample (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses). No exclusion criteria are violated (not an ROI-only, resting-state, or non-empirical paper; ages within 17–65). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study uses fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing (Toy Story), a stimulus with clear social-cognitive demands (theory of mind, social interactions). The sample includes a healthy adult group (final N=21 adults) within the target age range and reported adult-group results separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level statistical maps of inter-subject correlation (within-group inter-SC maps and Adult vs. Child contrasts) with multiple-comparison correction and peak coordinates, which are whole-brain task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. Although the analysis uses inter-subject correlation rather than a traditional GLM, the reported group-level voxel/nodewise statistical maps satisfy the criterion of whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social feedback task (social inclusion/exclusion) in a healthy sample (N=56 analyzed; ages 17–20), which falls within the review’s adult range (17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunctions) with voxelwise familywise-error correction and provides peak coordinates and conjunction maps. Analyses are reported for the healthy cohort (results not limited to a narrow subgroup), and are not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Participants are adolescents (N=34; ages 14–18, mean 16.3). Inclusion criterion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65 or a separately reported adult subgroup. This study does not report a separate adult (≥17) healthy group or analyses restricted to adults, and the sample is predominantly under 17. Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social reward and reports whole-brain group-level results (cluster coordinates in social-processing regions), the participant age range violates the sample inclusion criterion. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation (social-meaningful, social-irrelevant, non-social conditions). It reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables/figures of peak coordinates for the healthy participant groups. A healthy younger adult group (age 20–29) is analyzed and reported separately, meeting the 17–65 age requirement. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and presents whole-brain task activation maps/generalizable effects for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria appear violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of others varying by race and socioeconomic status), conducted in healthy adult participants (60 adult males, mean age 23.8). The task is a task-evoked, event-related impression-formation paradigm using faces (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain second-level GLMs and exploratory whole-brain regression results (clusters for the main effect of status and a VMPFC cluster), in addition to ROI analyses. Whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates are described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (only ROIs, only connectivity, non-healthy sample, or no whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.
